text: Two telephone operators sit at switchboard busy plugging and out answering calls.
This is the Morning Post... The City  Room? Just a moment, I'll connect  you. (plugs in call)
Morning Post... Sports Department?  Just a moment -- (plugs in call)

CAMERA PULLS BACK to disclose the rest of the anteroom. T Camera left are the elevators -- at back wall directly be switchboard are chairs and a table for visitors. Next to  switchboard are stairs leading downward to the next floor waist-high iron grill with a gate in it separates the  switchboard from the anteroom, a similar grill separating again from the city room which stretches on beyond  switchboard. At a table in the switchboard enclosure sits office boy, about fifteen, doing a crossword puzzle. The clock on the back wall shows that it is nearly one o'cloc
as he bends over paper. We catch a glimpse of the squares a crossword puzzle.
as a reporter comes out of the City Room, clanging gate t behind him. The office boy looks up.
What's a seven-letter word for --?
Don't ask me! If I knew any seven- letter words, I'd be something better  than a reporter!
He catches a glimpse of the far elevator going down.
Hey! Down! Down!

as reporter runs in to the closed elevator door and pound on it. It comes back, the door opens, and he gets in. The door closes, as elevator goes down. The near elevator com up and discharges Hildy Johnson and Bruce Baldwin. Bruce  carries an umbrella and wears a raincoat.
office boy looking over his puzzle as Hildy and Bruce com into the scene.
(with a smile) Hello, Skinny. Remember me?
(looks up; then a  glowing smile) Hildy Johnson!
Hildy approaches the switchboard.
(to operator) Hello, Maisie.
The first operator looks up.
Hello -- Hildy! You coming back?
No, just visiting. Tell me, is the  lord of the universe in today?
He is -- and in a very bad humor. I  think somebody stole one of his crown  jewels. Shall I announce you?
No, never mind -- I'll blow my own  trumpet.
Hildy turns to Bruce.
I won't be more than ten minutes, I  promise you.
Even ten minutes is a long time to  be away from you.
We hear a giggle off scene.
He looks towards Bruce and Hildy and giggles.
What did you say, Bruce?
Bruce, embarrassed, looks at the office boy, then looks b at Hildy as they turn toward second gate leading into Cit Room.
I said -- uh -- I said even ten  minutes -- is a long time -- to be  away from you.
Don't be embarrassed, Bruce. I heard  it, but I just wanted to hear it  again. I can stand being spoiled a  little. The gentleman I'm going to  have a chat with did very little  spoiling.
(grimly) I'd like to spoil him just once.  Sure you don't want me to go in with  you?
My job, Bruce. I started it -- and  I'll finish it.
I suppose you're right -- but if it  gets rough, remember I'm here.
I'll come a-running, pardner.
She starts to push open the iron-grilled gate leading int the City Room. Bruce quickly springs forward and opens it for her. Hildy smiles.
Thanks, Bruce.
She kisses his cheek and walks through. He looks after he The office boy whistles. Bruce pays no attention, but sta after Hildy.

head_text.subj: SHOOTING DOWN LENGTH OF CITY ROOM

text: Hildy starts to walk through City Room.

as she walks the length of the City Room. It's a long wal because it's a room that takes up practically the whole f The scene is a busy one. But, gradually, as Hildy starts  down, one after another recognize her. There are cries of "Hildy!" "Hello, Hildy", etc., from the men as Hildy goes straight down the aisle. She never stops but waves her ow greetings: "Jim!" "Hi, good-looking!" "Laura" "Hullo, Pop "Nan!" "Eddie!" "Hello, Mac" "Pete!" "Frank" "Oscar!", an gets responses from each of them. One man is bent over hi desk reading his copy -- he is standing up. Hildy slaps h as she goes by. He turns around: "Say, who did that?" As sees Hildy: "Hello, Hildy!" Hildy: "Hi, Jake." She passes middle-aged woman, almost an Edna May Oliver type, seated a desk pounding out copy and smoking a cigarette. As Hild comes up to her she slaps the woman on the back.
Hello, Beatrice. How's "Advice to  the Lovelorn"?
(looking up) Hildy! I'll be a monkey's uncle!  What are you doing here?
Point of information -- what does a  girl say on meeting her divorced  husband? OR: (What does a girl do,  etc.)
(illustrating) My advice is duck and cross with  your right.
Hildy moves on. CAMERA TRUCKS WITH HER to the end of the  room where she pauses before the frosted glass partition  which separates Walter Burns' office from the rest of the City Room.
as she opens the door. Burns is shaving with an electric  razor and Louie is holding the mirror up in front of him.
shaving, Louie holding the mirror.
A little more round the chin, Boss.
There is a sound of the door closing and Burns, without  looking up, says:
What do you want?
Why, I'm surprised, Mr. Burns. That's  no way to talk to your wife -- even  if she's no longer your wife.
(grinning) Hello, Hildy!
Hello, Walter. (to Louie) Hi, Louie -- how's the slotmachine  king?
Oh, I ain't doing that any more. I'm  retired. I'm one of you fellas now --  a newspaper man.
Editorials?
Get going, Louie. I got company.
The door flies open and Duffy comes busting in.
Walter!
I'm busy, Duffy.
Well, you're not too busy to know  that the Governor hasn't signed that  reprieve!
What?
And that means Earl Williams dies  tomorrow morning and makes a sucker  out of us!
You're crazy. Where's Mac?
He's on my phone. He just called me.
They can't do that to me!
He grabs the phone on his desk:

Give me that call on Duffy's wire!  Hello -- Mac? Burns. Where's the  Governor? -- What do you mean, you  can't locate him? (apparently pleading  to the one man in  the world who can  help him) Mac, you know what this means. We're  the only paper in town defending  Earl Williams and if he hangs tomorrow  we're washed up! Find the Governor  and when you find him tell him we  want that reprieve!... Tell him I  elected him and I can have him  impeached! Sure, you can do it, Mac --  I know you can. I always said you  were the greatest reporter in the  country and now you can prove it.  Get going! Attaboy!
He hangs up.

(to Duffy,  sarcastically) The greatest reporter in the country!  First I gotta tell him what news to  get! Gotta tell him how to get it --  then I gotta write it for him  afterward! Now if you were a decent  City Editor --
with Louie and Hildy in the b.g.
Don't blame me. I'm City Editor in  name only. You do all the hiring  around here.
Yeah! Well, I do the firing, too.  Remember that, Duffy, and Keep a  civil tongue in your head.
I don't like to interfere with  business, but would you boys pardon  us while we have a little heart-to- heart talk?
(together) Well -- But I gotta --
They look at Burns.
Scram, you guys.
They start to go.
You won't miss anything. You'll  probably be able to hear him just as  well outside as here.
They go.
Mind if I sit down?
Hildy sits.
going out of the door. They cast an interested look back linger a second. Over scene comes Burns' voice.
I said scram!
They close the door hurriedly.
May I have a cigarette, please?
Burns reaches into his pocket, extracts a cigarette and t it on the desk. Hildy reaches for it.
Thanks. A match?
Burns delves into pockets again, comes up with matchbox,  tosses it to Hildy, who catches it deftly, and strikes th match.
How long is it?
Hildy finishes lighting her cigarette, takes a puff, and  fans out the match.
How long is what?
You know what. How long since we've  seen each other?
Let's see. I was in Reno six weeks --  then Bermuda... Oh, about four months,  I guess. Seems like yesterday to me.
(slyly) Maybe it was yesterday. Been seeing  me in your dreams?
(casually) No -- Mama doesn't dream about you  any more, Walter. You wouldn't know  the old girl now.
(with conviction) Oh, yes I would. I'd know you any  time --
He grows lyrical and, rising from his seat, is about to s toward her, as he continues:
(together) -- any place, anywhere --
He sits.
(half-pityingly) You're repeating yourself! That's  the speech you made the night you  proposed. (she burlesques his  fervor) "-- any time -- any place --  anywhere!"
(growling) I notice you still remember it.
I'll always remember it. If I hadn't  remembered it, I wouldn't have  divorced you.
You know, Hildy, I sort of wish you  hadn't done it.
Done what?
Divorced me. It sort of makes a fellow  lose faith in himself. It almost  gives him a feeling he wasn't wanted.
Holy mackerel! Look, Walter, that's  what divorces are for.

Nonsense. You've got the old-fashioned  idea that divorces are something  that last forever -- till 'death us  do part'. Why, a divorce doesn't  mean anything today. It's only a few  words mumbled over you by a judge.  We've got something between us nothing  can change.
I suppose that's true in a way. I am  fond of you, Walter. I often wish  you weren't such a stinker.
Now, that's a nice thing to say.
Well, why did you promise me you  wouldn't fight the divorce and then  try and gum up the whole works?
Well, I meant to let you go -- but,  you know, you never miss the water  till the well runs dry.

A fellow your age, hiring an airplane  to write: (she gestures above  to indicate sky- writing) 'Hildy: Don't be hasty -- remember  my dimple. Walter.! It held things  up twenty minutes while the Judge  ran out to watch it.
Well, I don't want to brag, but I've  still got the dimple -- and in the  same place -- I just acted like any  husband who doesn't want to see his  home broken up.
What home?
What home? Don't you remember the  home I promised you?
Oh, yes -- we were to have it right  after our honeymoon -- honeymoon!
Was it my fault? Did I know that  coal mine was going to have another  cave-in? I meant to be with you on  our honeymoon, Hildy -- honest I  did.

All I know is that instead of two  weeks in Atlantic City with my  bridegroom, I spent two weeks in a  coal mine with John Kruptzky -- age  sixty-three -- getting food and air  out of a tube! You don't deny that.  Do you?
Deny it! I'm proud of it! We beat  the whole country on that story.

Well, suppose we did? That isn't  what I got married for. What's the  good of -- Look, Walter, I came up  here to tell you that you'll have to  stop phoning me a dozen times a day --  sending twenty telegrams -- all the  rest of it, because I'm --
Let's not fight, Hildy. Tell you  what. You come back to work on the  paper and if we find we can't get  along in a friendly way, we'll get  married again.
What?!!
I haven't any hard feelings.
Walter, you're wonderful in a  loathesome sort of way. Now, would  you mind keeping quiet long enough  for me to tell you what I came up  here for?
(rising, reaching for  his hat) Sure, come on. We'll have some lunch  and you can tell me everything.
(also rising) I have a lunch date. I just want --
You can break it, can't you?
No, I can't.
Sure you can. Come on.
Don't tell me what to do! We're  divorced -- I'm a free woman. You're  not my husband and you're not my  boss! And what's more, you're not  going to be my boss.
What do you mean by that?
Just what I said. That's what I --
You mean you're not coming back to  work here?
That's the first time you've been  right today. That's what I --
(still interrupting) You've had a better offer, eh?
You bet I've got a better offer.
Well, go on and take it. Work for  somebody else! That's the gratitude  I get for --
I know, Walter, but I --
(ignoring her) What were you when you came here  five years ago? A little college  girl from a School of Journalism! I  took a little doll-faced mugg --
You wouldn't have taken me if I hadn't  been doll-faced!
Why should I? I thought it would be  a novelty to have a face around here  a man could look at without  shuddering.
Listen, Walter --
(going right on) I made a great reporter out of you,  Hildy, but you won't be half as good  on any other paper, and you know it.  You need me and I need you -- and  the paper needs both of us.
Well, the paper'll have to learn to  do without me. And so will you. It  just didn't work out, Walter.
It would have worked if you'd been  satisfied with just being editor and  reporter. But no! You had to marry  me and spoil everything.
(indignantly) I wasn't satisfied! I suppose I  proposed to you!

Well, you practically did! Making  goo-goo eyes at me for two years  till I broke down. And I still claim  I was tight the night I proposed. If  you'd been a gentleman you'd have  forgotten all about it. But not you!
(speechless) You -- you --
She grabs something and chucks it at him. He ducks. The p rings.
(to Hildy) You're losing your eye. You used to  be able to pitch better than that. (he reaches for phone) Hello... Yeah... What? Sweeney? Well,  what can I do for you?
seated at his desk, talking into phone.
What's the matter with you? Are you  drunk? This is Duffy, not Sweeney!
Burns into phone:

Sweeney! You can't do that to me!  Not today, of all days! Jumping  Jehosophat! Oh, no, Sweeney... Well,  I suppose so... All right. If you  have to, you have to. (he hangs up) How do you like that? Everything  happens to me -- with 365 days in  the year -- this has to be the day.
What's the matter?
Sweeney.
Dead?
Not yet. Might just as well be. The  only man on the paper who can write --  and his wife picks this morning to  have a baby!
Sweeney? (she laughs) Well, after all, he didn't do it on  purpose, did he?
I don't care whether he did or not.  He's supposed to be covering the  Earl Williams case and there he is --  waiting at the hospital! Is there no  sense of honor left in this country?
(practically) Well, haven't you got anybody else?
There's nobody else on the paper who  can write! This'll break me, unless -- (he stares at Hildy;  then a light breaks) Hildy!
No!
You've got to help me, Hildy.
Keep away --
It'll bring us together again, Hildy --  just the way we used to be.
That's what I'm afraid of. "Any time --  any place -- anywhere!"
Don't mock, Hildy, this is bigger  than anything that's happened to us.  Don't do it for me! Do it for the  paper.
Get away, Svengali.
If you won't do it for love, how  about money? Forget the other offer  and I'll raise you twenty-five bucks  a week.
Listen, you bumble-headed baboon --
All right -- thirty-five, and not a  cent more!
Please! Will you just --
Great grief! What's that other paper  going to give you?
I'm not working for any other paper!
Oh! In that case, the raise is off  and you go back to your old salary  and like it. Trying to blackjack --
Look at this! (pulling her glove  off her left hand)
She gets glove off left hand and holds up an engagement r for him to see.
Do you see this? Do you know what an  engagement ring is?
He looks at ring, swallows, then:
Burns and Hildy.
I tried to tell you right away but  you started reminiscing. I'm getting  married, Walter, and also getting as  far away from the newspaper business  as I can get! I'm through.
(himself again) Get married all you want to, Hildy,  but you can't quit the newspaper  business.
You can't sell me that, Walter.
Who says I can't? You're a newspaper  man.
That's why I'm quitting. I want to  go some place where I can be a woman.
I know you, Hildy, and I know what  it would mean. It would kill you.

(bitterly) A journalist! Peeking through keyholes --  running after fire engines -- waking  people up in the middle of the night  to ask them if they think Hitler's  going to start a war -- stealing  pictures off old ladies of their  daughters that got chased by apemen!  I know all about reporters -- a lot  of daffy buttinskies going around  without a nickel in their pockets,  and for what? So a million hired  girls and motormen's wives will know  what's going on! No, Walter, I'm  through.
Where'd you meet this man?
Bermuda.
Bermuda... Rich, eh?
Not what you'd call rich. Makes about  five thousand a year.
What's his line?
He's in the insurance business.
(looks up) The insurance business?
(on the defensive) It's a good, honest business, isn't  it?
Oh sure, it's honest. But somehow, I  can't picture you with a guy who  sells policies.
Well, I can, and I love it! He forgets  the office when he's with me. He  doesn't treat me like an errand-boy --  he treats me like a woman.
He does, does he? How did I treat  you -- like a water buffalo?
I don't know about water buffaloes,  but I know about him. He's kind and  sweet and considerate. He wants a  home -- and children.
Say, sounds more like a guy I ought  to marry. What's his name?
Well, I'll give you a hint. By  tomorrow they'll be calling me Mrs.  Bruce Baldwin.
Tomorrow? Tomorrow... as quick as  that?
The quicker the better. Well -- I  finally got out what I came in to  tell you. (she extends her hand) So long, Walter, and better luck  next time.
(taking her hand) I wish you everything I couldn't  give you, Hildy.
Thanks...
Too bad I couldn't see this guy first.  I'm pretty particular about whom my  wife marries.
(laughing) Well, he's waiting in the anteroom  for me now.
Say, could I meet him?
Oh, better not, Walter. Wouldn't do  any good.
You're not afraid, are you?
Afraid? I should say not!
All right then, come on and let's  see this paragon. (gets hat) Is he as good as you say?
Better.
Burns has his hat. They start toward the door.
Then what does he want with you?
(laughing) Now you got me.
Nothing personal. I was just asking.
At the door, Burns walks ahead, opens door and walks out.
After all --
He stops as he realizes she's not there. The door opens.  Hildy comes out.
You wouldn't believe this, Walter,  but Bruce holds the door open for  me.
(incredulous) No kidding?
Reporters conversing. They stop as Hildy and Burns enter  scene.
as Hildy follows Burns through the City Room. This time, contrast to Hildy's original walk through the room, the g are silent as they watch the two.
(trying to keep pace) And he takes his hat off when he's  with a lady.
(over his shoulder) What for?
(shouting) And when he walks with a lady, he  waits for her!
(stops) Oh, I'm sorry.
Burns, at this point, has reached the switchboard. He say under his breath, to Maisie:
(under his breath) Have Duffy call me in the restaurant  in twenty minutes.
Hildy, a little out of breath, catches up with him. At th iron gate that opens into anteroom Hildy jumps ahead, ope the gate and holds it for Burns.
Allow me.
(walking right through) Thanks.
Hildy follows him out.
as Hildy follows Burns in. Bruce is sitting on the bench. the end of a bench sits an old, grizzled Western Union "b Ignoring Bruce, Burns strides over to the "boy", seizes h hand, shakes it and says:
I can see right away my wife picked  out the right husband for herself.
Hildy behind him. Bruce registers amazement at this.
The messenger is more amazed than Bruce as Burns keeps pu his hand vigorously.
There must be some mistake. I'm  already married.
(you never saw a more  surprised man) Already married! (turning to Hildy  o.s.) Hildy, why didn't you tell me?
She shakes her head at Burns' antics, but can't help smil nevertheless.
(again seizing  messenger's hand) Congratulations again, Mr. Baldwin!
But my name --
(as he enters scene) Mr. Burns!
Burns turns slightly but doesn't release messenger's hand
Yeah? You'll have to excuse me --  I'm busy with Mr. Bruce Baldwin here.  Just leave your card with the boy.
Bruce takes hold of Burns' coat and shakes it to get his  attention. Burns turns on him:
I'm very sorry, but I'm busy! Look -- (he points o.s.) -- there's the boy. Take your card  and leave it with him.
He turns away again. Bruce, determinedly, takes hold of h sleeve and pulls at it.
Mr. Burns --
(wheeling around) I've just told you I was busy with  Mr. Bruce Baldwin!
I'm Bruce Baldwin!
Burns, still pumping the dazed messenger's hand, stops at this, drops hand, and turns to Bruce:
You're Bruce Baldwin?
Yes!
(accusing to messenger) Then who are you?
(falteringly) My name's Pete Davis.
Pete Davis! Well, Mr. Davis, this is  no concern of yours and after this  I'll thank you to keep out of my  affairs!
The messenger isn't quite sure what he's done but he slin back to his seat as Burns turns to Bruce.
She is beginning to get sore, but reluctantly again she i compelled to smile at Walter's behavior.
(reaches for Bruce's  hand but grabs the  umbrella and begins  shaking the handle  up and down) This is a pleasure, Mr. Baldwin, and  I'm sorry about the mistake.
(he tries to shift  the umbrella, calling  Burns' attention to  it, and offers his  hand instead)
Oh, I thought there was something  funny... You see, Bruce, you don't  mind if I call you Bruce, do you?  After all, we're practically related --
(completely unnerved  by this time, and  you can't quite blame  him) Mr. -- well -- no -- no -- not at  all.
You see, my wife -- I mean, your  wife -- that is, I mean Hildy -- had  led me to expect that she was marrying  a much older man.
(this is the final  crusher) Oh.
But I see, she didn't mean old in  years. You always carry an umbrella,  Bruce?
Well, er -- it looked a little cloudy  this morning.
That's right. -- Rubbers, too, I  hope? A man ought to be prepared for  any emergency.
Burns looks down. Bruce, in unconscious responses, helple lifts his foot up and we see the rubber.
Attaboy! (taking Bruce's arm  and leading him toward  elevator) Come on, Bruce.
(going along, but  worried) Where are we going?
Where are we going? I'm going to buy  you two lunch -- didn't Hildy tell  you?
(a helpless look back  at Hildy) No -- she didn't.

Just wanted to surprise you, I guess. (as the elevator is  about to pass, he  calls) Down! (practically shoving  Bruce in) After you, Bruce! (as Bruce disappears  inside he turns toward  Hildy) Come on, Hildy, my treat!
We don't see the passengers. Hildy comes into scene.
I suppose I can't call this off  without creating a scene -- but  remember, it's your last fling.
(hurt) How do you like that? Here I am being  nice to you and your sweet-heart and  that's the thanks I get!
He jumps into the elevator -- in a second he hops out.
(very sweetly -- he  almost sings it) Oh -- after you, Hildy!
With a look of disgust Hildy gets in. Burns follows and t door slams on them.
He looks after departed elevator and whistles. Then he gr all over.

head_text.subj: HE GRINS ALL OVER AND SAYS

text: Don't tell me it's you, Hildy!
CAMERA PULLS BACK and discloses our three at a restaurant table. Nothing swanky -- a place like Jack Blake's in New York, say.
(beaming at waiter) Nobody else.
She extends her hand. The waiter takes it; they shake.
How's everything, Gus?
I can't complain.
(studying menu) Well, I can. I'm hungry. Roast beef  sandwich -- rare. And some coffee.
Shall I put a little rum in the  coffee? It's a nasty day.
Good idea. How about you, Hildy?
(discarding menu) Oh -- I'll take the same, I guess.  And coffee.
Little rum in yours, too?
I guess so.
Bruce looks at her. She hurriedly changes her mind.
No -- just coffee, Gus.
(crestfallen) Just coffee. (to Bruce) And you, sir?
(putting menu down) Oh, I'll take the same, I guess. And  a glass of milk.
(incredulous) Milk?
(thinks he hasn't  heard) Yes.
(shaking his head as  he writes it down) Milk.
And don't put any rum in it, Gus.
Gus gives him a look and goes.
Burns surveys the others quizzically.
(a sigh) Well, so you're getting married  tomorrow, eh? How does it feel, Bruce?
Feels awful good. Yes, sir -- we're  taking the four o'clock train to  Albany and tomorrow we'll be married.
(it's the Puritan in  him) Taking the train today -- and being  married tomorrow?
He whistles.
(rising to the bait) Oh, it isn't like that.
(reassuring Mrs. Grundy) It will be perfectly all right,  Walter. Mother is coming with us on  the train.
Mother? But your mother --
No. My mother.
(he gets it and  underlines it) Oh. Your mother -- well, of course,  that relieves my mind.
(to Bruce) Isn't it sweet of Walter -- still  wanting to protect me?
She gives Burns that too-sweet look.
(apparently taking  this at face value) I know I wasn't a good husband, Hildy,  but you can always count on me.
(a little cookily) I don't think she'll need you very  much -- I aim to do most of the  protecting myself.
He pats Hildy's arm -- she smiles at him.
Well, I'll tell you one thing, old  man, she never looked at me the way  she's looking at you.
I might have, Walter, but you were  never there.

Anyway, I'm glad you two are going  to be happy and have all the things  I couldn't give her. You know, Hildy  is about the best reporter in the  country -- and that goes regardless  of sex. But all she really ever wanted  was a home.
Well, I'll try to give her one.
I know you will, Bruce. Are you going  to live with your mother?
Just for the first year.
(sighing) That'll be nice. A home with mother.  A real honeymoon. In Albany, too.  Ow!
That "ow" is sotto voce, but it's the direct result of a  kick under the table from Hildy.
Mighty nice little town, Albany.  They've got the State Capitol there,  you know.
Yes, I know... (he chuckles) Hildy, will you ever forget the night  you brought the Governor back to  your hotel room and found me taking  a bath? She didn't even know I was  in town...
His laugh stops cold and he clutches for his shin again.  Hildy just looks. Providentially, the waiter enters the s
Well, here we are.
He begins serving them.
(trying to pick up  again after a second) How's business, Bruce?
Well, Albany's a mighty good insurance  town. Most people there take it out  pretty early in life.
I don't blame them.
Gus, who has just managed to come between Hildy and Burns lets out a startled "ouch".
Oh, I'm sorry, Gus! My foot must  have slipped.
(a pained expression  belies his words) That's all right.
I sometimes wish I'd taken out  insurance -- but, of course, now it  doesn't matter. Still, I suppose it  would have been the smart thing to  do.
Well, I honestly feel that way. I  figure I'm in one line of business  that really helps people. Of course,  we don't help you much when you're  alive -- but afterward -- that's  what counts.
I see what you mean.
They fall to.
She sips her coffee and acts surprised.
Gus, this --
(winking) Good coffee, isn't it?
She smiles and winks back, and takes another sip.
Gus starts to go.
You've forgotten my milk.
Oh. The milk. Yes.
He leaves scene, shaking his head. Burns sips his coffee. likes it. He lifts his cup to Hildy.
Here's luck to the bride and  bridegroom.
(lifts cup) Thank you.
(looking for something  to respond with --  apologetically) He hasn't brought my milk yet.
A bus boy comes into scene and stops before Burns.
They want you on the phone, Mr. Burns.
They would!
Boy goes, Burns rises, starts off, comes back for his cup coffee, which he then takes off with him.
(looking after him) You know, Hildy, he's not a bad  fellow.
(looking at him  maternally) You're so nice, Bruce, you think  everybody else is.
Oh, he's not the man for you. I can  see that. But I sort of like him.  Got a lot of charm.
He comes by it naturally. His  grandfather was a snake.
